oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Free Hill School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools; Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of one-story side-gable wooden schoolhouse viewed from driveway as approached from rear. This side of the building features two banks of double-hung eight-over-eight light windows arranged as a group of three and a pair on either side of a brick chimney. The building rests on a block and brick foundation. A basketball hoop is near the building. A sign reading Free Hills Community Center is in the foreground.

The Free Hill Rosenwald School was built circa 1929-1930 with assistance from the Julius Rosenwald Foundation. The only Rosenwald school built in Clay County, it operated as a school until 1966. It currently serves as a community center. The community of Free Hill is located five miles northeast of Celina, Tennessee, and was organized by former slaves. Virginia Hill, a slaveholder originally from North Carolina, freed her slaves and gave them 2,000 acres of land. The former slaves named their community Free Hill.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Center for Historic Preservation, Middle Tennessee State University
